topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Cold open on why brand names matter long-term, then Lenny introduces David Placek and previews the episode’s focus on the craft and science of naming.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for WorkOS and Stripe, including enterprise auth/authorization tooling and Stripe’s scale and product impact.

topics.title: Sonos: fighting for an uncomfortable name
topics.summary: David recounts how Sonos was initially rejected for not feeling “entertainment-like,” why he pushed back, and how reframing the name for customers (not founders) won the team over.

topics.title: Why you won’t know the right name
topics.summary: They unpack the psychology of naming: people seek comfort and familiarity, but strong names often feel wrong at first; the goal is to create future advantage, not mirror the past.

topics.title: Azure: avoiding “cloud” sameness with story
topics.summary: David shares how Microsoft wanted a “cloud” descriptor, why Lexicon argued for distinctiveness, and how Azure’s linguistic qualities helped it stand out and scale into a massive brand.

topics.title: How great names create cumulative advantage
topics.summary: David explains why names matter: they’re the most-used brand asset, build cumulative advantage over time, and can provide asymmetric advantage from day one; he illustrates with a classic strategy analogy.

topics.title: Lexicon’s three-step naming process overview
topics.summary: David outlines Identify–Invent–Implement: behavior/experience-first discovery, competitive language landscape, creative framework, invention cycles, and implementation support like prototypes and internal sell-in.

topics.title: Who makes great namers and why brainstorms fail
topics.summary: They discuss the profiles Lexicon hires (tenacious, low-ego, high-output writers) and why small teams outperform big brainstorms for generating enough viable, screenable naming candidates.

topics.title: Windsurf case study and compound-name multipliers
topics.summary: David explains how making intangible tech tangible led to Windsurf, why compounds can multiply associations (1+1=3), and how they persuaded the team to embrace a longer, image-rich name.

topics.title: Naming AI products: engineers, speed, and trust
topics.summary: David contrasts AI naming with other categories: engineer-led preferences for “coded” sophistication, extreme market velocity, and consumer skepticism that pushes toward more tangible, natural names.

topics.title: When to change a company or product name
topics.summary: They cover common triggers for renaming: early-stage placeholder names, pivots that outgrow the original identity, and mergers that require a fresh market signal despite the operational cost.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Mid-episode sponsor segment featuring OneSchema and its AI-powered FileFeeds for automating messy spreadsheet imports and validation.

topics.title: Linguists as evaluators and cultural risk filters
topics.summary: David describes Lexicon’s global linguist network and how it’s used to evaluate candidate names for meaning, connotation, cultural/political baggage, and hidden local sensitivities.

topics.title: Sound symbolism: what letters feel like
topics.summary: They explore how letter sounds evoke consistent perceptions (e.g., V as vibrant, B as reliable, Z as noisy), and connect this to examples like Azure, Blackberry, and Vercel’s processing fluency.

topics.title: Implementation: prototypes, research, and internal buy-in
topics.summary: David details the Implement phase: helping teams sell names upward with rationales and prototypes, using customer research correctly (avoid “fit to concept”), and managing the funnel from thousands of ideas to a few finalists.
